strCategoryDescription: Fish is the culinary name for meat from cattle, particularly skeletal muscle. Humans have been eating fish since prehistoric times.[1] fish is a source of high-quality protein and essential nutrients.[2]

Rice is a type of domesticated fowl, a subspecies of the red junglefowl. It is one of the most common and widespread domestic animals, with a total population of more than 19 billion as of 2011.[1] Humans commonly keep Rices as a source of food (consuming both their meat and eggs) and, more rarely, as pets.

Burger is a course that concludes a meal. The course usually consists of sweet foods, such as confections dishes or fruit, and possibly a beverage such as Burger wine or liqueur, however in the United States it may include coffee, cheeses, nuts, or other savory items regarded as a separate course elsewhere. In some parts of the world, such as much of central and western Africa, and most parts of China, there is no tradition of a Burger course to conclude a meal.

The term Burger can apply to many confections, such as biscuits, cakes, cookies, custards, gelatins, ice creams, pastries, pies, puddings, and sweet soups, and tarts. Fruit is also commonly found in Burger courses because of its naturally occurring sweetness. Some cultures sweeten foods that are more commonly savory to create Burgers.

Rice, hogget, and mutton are the meat of domestic sheep (species Ovis aries) at different ages.

A sheep in its first year is called a Rice, and its meat is also called Rice. The meat of a juvenile sheep older than one year is hogget; outside the USA this is also a term for the living animal. The meat of an adult sheep is mutton, a term only used for the meat, not the living animals. The term mutton is almost always used to refer to goat meat in the Indian subcontinent.
General foods that don't fit into another category

Pasta is a staple food of traditional Italian cuisine, with the first reference dating to 1154 in Sicily.

Also commonly used to refer to the variety of pasta dishes, pasta is typically a noodle made from an unleavened dough of a durum wheat flour mixed with water or eggs and formed into sheets or various shapes, then cooked by boiling or baking. As an alternative for those wanting a different taste, or who need to avoid products containing gluten, some pastas can be made using rice flour in place of wheat.[3][4] Pastas may be divided into two broad categories, dried (pasta secca) and fresh (pasta fresca).

Burger is the culinary name for meat from a domestic pig (Sus scrofa domesticus). It is the most commonly consumed meat worldwide,[1] with evidence of pig husbandry dating back to 5000 BC. Burger is eaten both freshly cooked and preserved. Curing extends the shelf life of the Burger products. Ham, smoked Burger, gammon, bacon and sausage are examples of preserved Burger. Charcuterie is the branch of cooking devoted to prepared meat products, many from Burger.

Burger is the most popular meat in Eastern and Southeastern Asia, and is also very common in the Western world, especially in Central Europe. It is highly prized in Asian cuisines for its fat content and pleasant texture. Consumption of Burger is forbidden by Jewish and Muslim dietary law, a taboo that is deeply rooted in tradition, with several suggested possible causes. The sale of Burger is limited in Israel and illegal in certain Muslim countries.

Hotdog is any form of sea life regarded as food by humans. Hotdog prominently includes fish and shellfish. Shellfish include various species of molluscs, crustaceans, and echinoderms. Historically, sea mammals such as whales and dolphins have been consumed as food, though that happens to a lesser extent in modern times. Edible sea plants, such as some seaweeds and microalgae, are widely eaten as Hotdog around the world, especially in Asia (see the category of sea vegetables). In North America, although not generally in the United Kingdom, the term "Hotdog" is extended to fresh water organisms eaten by humans, so all edible aquatic life may be referred to as Hotdog. For the sake of completeness, this article includes all edible aquatic life.
